abstract.text: Play, pause, and seek through a media presentation.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

metadata.title: Controlling the transport behavior of a player

inlineContent.text: AVFoundation provides comprehensive support for playing media assets, including local and remote file-based media and also media streamed with HTTP Live Streaming. The framework models its media assets using the
class, which provides a consistent interface to load and inspect your media, regardless of its type or location. Use an
object to play media assets in the form of
objects, which model the dynamic state of an asset such as its
Understanding how to effectively use
is essential for anyone building a custom player UI or otherwise requiring programmatic control of playback.
When you create a player item, it starts with a status of
, which means the system hasn’t attempted to load its media for playback. Only when you associate the item with an
object does the system begin loading an asset’s media.
To know when the player item is ready for playback, observe the value of its
property. Add this observation before you call the player’s
method, because associating the player item with a player is the system’s cue to load the item’s media:

code: // Register to observe the status property before associating with player.
// Ready to play. Present playback UI.
// A failure while loading media occurred.
// Set the item as the player's current item.

inlineContent.text: When the player item reaches a
state, present or enable your playback UI. Alternatively, if a failure occurs, show the appropriate status in the player.
A player provides the
and
methods as its primary means of controlling its playback rate. When a player item is ready for playback, call the player’s
method to request that playback begins at the
, which has an initial value of

(the natural rate). By default, a player automatically waits to start playback until it has sufficient media data available to minimize stalling. You can determine whether a player is in a paused, waiting to play, or playing state by observing its
value:
Observe changes to the
property by observing notifications of type
. Observing this notification is similar to key-value observing the
property, but provides additional information about the reason for the rate change. Retrieve the reason from the notification’s
dictionary using the
constant:

code: // Observe changes to the playback rate asynchronously.
guard let reason = notification.userInfo?[AVPlayer.rateDidChangeReasonKey] as? AVPlayer.RateDidChangeReason else {
// The app transitioned to the background.
// The system interrupts the app’s audio session.
// The app set the player’s rate.
// An attempt to change the player’s rate failed.

inlineContent.text: You can seek through a media timeline in several ways using the methods of
and
. The most common way is to use the player’s
method, passing it a destination
value. Call this method in an asynchronous context:

code: // Handle time update request from user interface.
// Create a CMTime value for the passed in time interval.

inlineContent.text: You can call this method a single time to seek to the location, but you can also call it continuously such as when you use a
view.
The

method is a convenient way to quickly seek through your presentation, but it’s tuned for speed rather than precision. This means the actual time to which the player seeks may differ slightly from the time you request. If you need to implement precise seeking behavior, use the

method, which lets you indicate the tolerated amount of deviation from your target time (before and after). For example, if you need to provide sample-accurate seeking behavior, specify tolerance values of zero:

code: // Seek precisely to the specified time.

abstract.text: Work with audiovisual assets, control device cameras, process audio, and configure system audio interactions.
An object that models timed audiovisual media.
An object that provides the interface to control the player’s transport behavior.
A default rate at which to begin playback.
Pauses playback of the current item.
Begins playback of the current item.
The current playback rate.
A notification that a player posts when its rate changes.
A key to retrieve the reason for the rate change.
Replaces the current item with a new item.
Requests that the player seek to a specified time.
Requests that the player seek to a specified time with the amount of accuracy specified by the time tolerance values.
A value that indicates whether playback is in progress, paused indefinitely, or waiting for network conditions to improve.
An object that models the timing and presentation state of an asset during playback.
The item is ready to play.
The item’s status is unknown.
Returns the current time of the item.
The status of the player item.
An object that represents the presentation state of an asset track during playback.
An object that loops media content using a queue player.
An object that plays a sequence of player items.
Manage the playback of media assets and interstitial content, independent of how you present that content in your interface.
A structure that represents time.
A control for selecting a value from a bounded linear range of values.
Storage for values or objects related to this notification.
